\chapter{The amgf Module}
\label{amgf::doc}\label{amgf:module-amgf}\label{amgf:welcome-to-amgf-s-documentation}\label{amgf:the-amgf-module}\index{amgf (module)}
Let $F(x) = \sum_{\nu \in \NN^d} F_{\nu} x^\nu$ be a multivariate power series with complex coefficients that converges in a neighborhood of the origin. Assume that $F = G/H$ for some functions $G$ and $H$ holomorphic in a neighborhood of the origin.
Assume also that $H$ is a polynomial.

This Python module for use within \href{http://www.sagemath.org}{Sage} computes asymptotics for the coefficients $F_{r \alpha}$ as $r \to \infty$ with $r \alpha \in \NN^d$ for $\alpha$ in a permissible subset of $d$-tuples of positive reals. 
More specifically, it computes arbitrary terms of the asymptotic expansion for $F_{r \alpha}$ when the asymptotics are controlled by a strictly minimal multiple point of the alegbraic variety $H = 0$.

The algorithms and formulas implemented here come from {\hyperref[amgf:rawi2008a]{{[}RaWi2008a{]}}}
and {\hyperref[amgf:rawi2012]{{[}RaWi2012{]}}}.

AUTHORS:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Alexander Raichev (2008-10-01): Initial version

\item {} 
Alexander Raichev (2010-09-28): Corrected many functions

\item {} 
Alexander Raichev (2010-12-15): Updated documentation

\item {} 
Alexander Raichev (2011-03-09): Fixed a division by zero bug in relative\_error()

\item {} 
Alexander Raichev (2011-04-26): Rewrote in object-oreinted style

\item {} 
Alexander Raichev (2011-05-06): Fixed bug in cohomologous\_integrand() and fixed \_crit\_cone\_combo() to work in SR

\item {} 
Alexander Raichev (2012-08-06): Major rewrite. Created class FFPD and moved functions around.

\item {} 
Alexander Raichev (2012-10-03): Fixed whitespace errors, added examples to those six functions missing them (which i overlooked), changed package name to a more descriptive title, made asymptotics methods work for univariate functions.

\end{itemize}

\index{FFPD (class in amgf)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{amgf:amgf.FFPD}\pysiglinewithargsret{\strong{class }\code{amgf.}\bfcode{FFPD}}{\emph{numerator=None}, \emph{denominator\_factored=None}, \emph{quotient=None}, \emph{reduce\_=True}}{}
Bases: \code{object}

Represents a fraction with factored polynomial denominator (FFPD)
$p/(q_1^{e_1} \cdots q_n^{e_n})$ by storing the parts $p$ and
$[(q_1, e_1), \ldots, (q_n, e_n)]$.
Here $q_1, \ldots, q_n$ are elements of a 0- or multi-variate factorial
polynomial ring $R$ , $q_1, \ldots, q_n$ are distinct irreducible elements
of $R$ , $e_1, \ldots, e_n$ are positive integers, and $p$ is a function
of the indeterminates of $R$ (a Sage Symbolic Expression).
An element $r$ with no polynomial denominator is represented as $[r, (,)]$.

AUTHORS:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Alexander Raichev (2012-07-26)

\end{itemize}
\index{algebraic\_dependence\_certificate() (amgf.FFPD method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{amgf:amgf.FFPD.algebraic_dependence_certificate}\pysiglinewithargsret{\bfcode{algebraic\_dependence\_certificate}}{}{}
Return the ideal $J$ of annihilating polynomials for the set
of polynomials \code{{[}q**e for (q, e) in self.denominator\_factored(){]}},
which could be the zero ideal.
The ideal $J$ lies in a polynomial ring over the field
\code{self.ring().base\_ring()} that has
\code{m = len(self.denominator\_factored())} indeterminates.
Return None if \code{self.ring()} is None.

\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{n+nb}{bool}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{decomp}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{sum}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{quotient}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{n}{G}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{H}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+go}{True}
\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{k}{for} \PYG{n}{r} \PYG{o+ow}{in} \PYG{n}{decomp}\PYG{p}{:}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }      \PYG{n}{J} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{r}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{algebraic\PYGZus{}dependence\PYGZus{}certificate}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }      \PYG{n}{J} \PYG{o+ow}{is} \PYG{n+nb+bp}{None} \PYG{o+ow}{or} \PYG{n}{J} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{n}{J}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{ring}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{ideal}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{...}
\PYG{g+go}{True}
\PYG{g+go}{True}
\PYG{g+go}{True}
\end{Verbatim}

NOTE:

Let $f = p/q$ where $q$ lies in a $d$ -variate polynomial ring
$K[X]$ for some field $K$.
Let $q_1^{e_1} \cdots q_n^{e_n}$ be the
unique factorization of $q$ in $K[X]$ into irreducible factors and
let $V_i$ be the algebraic variety $\{x\in L^d: q_i(x) = 0\}$ of
$q_i$ over the algebraic closure $L$ of $K$.
By {\hyperref[amgf:raic2012]{{[}Raic2012{]}}}, $f$ can be written as

(*)   $\sum p_A/\prod_{i \in A} q_i^{b_i}$,

where the $b_i$ are positive integers, each $p_A$ is a products
of $p$ and an element in $K[X]$,
and the sum is taken over all subsets
$A \subseteq \{1, \ldots, m\}$ such that $|A| \le d$ and
$\{q_i : i\in A\}$ is algebraically independent.

I call (*) an \emph{algebraic dependence decomposition} of $f$.
Algebraic dependence decompositions are not unique.

The algorithm used comes from {\hyperref[amgf:raic2012]{{[}Raic2012{]}}}.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{asymptotic\_decomposition() (amgf.FFPD method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{amgf:amgf.FFPD.asymptotic_decomposition}\pysiglinewithargsret{\bfcode{asymptotic\_decomposition}}{\emph{alpha}, \emph{asy\_var=None}}{}
Return a FFPDSum that has the same asymptotic expansion as \code{self}
in the direction \code{alpha} but each of whose FFPDs has a
denominator factorization of the form $[(q_1, 1), \ldots, (q_n, 1)]$,
where \code{n} is at most \code{d = self.dimension()}.
The output results from a Leinartas decomposition followed by a
cohomology decomposition.

INPUT:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\code{alpha} - A d-tuple of positive integers or symbolic variables.

\item {} 
\code{asy\_var} - (Optional; default=None) A symbolic variable with
respect to which to compute asymptotics.
If None is given the set \code{asy\_var = var('r')}.

\end{itemize}

EXAMPLES:

\index{asymptotics() (amgf.FFPD method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{amgf:amgf.FFPD.asymptotics}\pysiglinewithargsret{\bfcode{asymptotics}}{\emph{p}, \emph{alpha}, \emph{N}, \emph{asy\_var=None}, \emph{numerical=0}}{}
Return the first $N$ terms (some of which could be zero)
of the asymptotic expansion of the Maclaurin ray coefficients
$F_{r\alpha}$ of the function $F$ represented by \code{self}
as $r\to\infty$, where $r$ = \code{asy\_var} and \code{alpha} is a tuple of
positive integers of length \code{d = self.dimension()}.
Assume that
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
$F$ is holomorphic in a neighborhood of the origin;

\item {} 
the unique factorization of the denominator $H$ of $F$ in the local 
algebraic ring at \$p\$ equals its unique factorization in the local 
analytic ring at \$p\$;

\item {} 
the unique factorization of $H$ in the local algebraic ring at $p$
has \$\textless{}= d\$ irreducible factors, none of which are repeated
(one can reduce to this case via asymptotic\_decomposition());

\item {} 
$p$ is a convenient strictly minimal smooth or multiple point
with all nonzero coordinates that is critical and nondegenerate
for \code{alpha}.

\end{itemize}

INPUT:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\code{p} - A dictionary with keys that can be coerced to equal
\code{self.ring().gens()}.

\item {} 
\code{alpha} - A tuple of length \code{self.dimension()} of
positive integers or, if \$p\$ is a smooth point,
possibly of symbolic variables.

\item {} 
\code{N} - A positive integer.

\item {} 
\code{numerical} - (Optional; default=0) A natural number.
If numerical \textgreater{} 0, then return a numerical approximation
of \$F\_\{r alpha\}\$ with \code{numerical} digits of precision.
Otherwise return exact values.

\item {} 
\code{asy\_var} - (Optional; default=None) A  symbolic variable.
The variable of the asymptotic expansion.
If none is given, \code{var('r')} will be assigned.

\end{itemize}

OUTPUT:

The tuple (asy, exp\_scale, subexp\_part).
Here asy is the sum of the first $N$ terms (some of which might be 0)
of the asymptotic expansion of $F_{r\alpha}$ as $r\to\infty$;
exp\_scale**r is the exponential factor of asy;
subexp\_part is the subexponential factor of asy.

EXAMPLES:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

\end{Verbatim}

\index{asymptotics\_multiple() (amgf.FFPD method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{amgf:amgf.FFPD.asymptotics_multiple}\pysiglinewithargsret{\bfcode{asymptotics\_multiple}}{\emph{p}, \emph{alpha}, \emph{N}, \emph{asy\_var}, \emph{coordinate=None}, \emph{numerical=0}}{}
Does what asymptotics() does but only in the case of a
convenient multiple point nondegenerate for alpha.
Assume also that \code{self.dimension \textgreater{}= 2} and that the 
\code{p.values()} are not symbolic variables.

INPUT:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\code{p} - A dictionary with keys that can be coerced to equal
\code{self.ring().gens()}.

\item {} 
\code{alpha} - A tuple of length \code{d = self.dimension()} of
positive integers or, if \$p\$ is a smooth point,
possibly of symbolic variables.

\item {} 
\code{N} - A positive integer.

\item {} 
\code{asy\_var} - (Optional; default=None) A symbolic variable.
The variable of the asymptotic expansion.
If none is given, \code{var('r')} will be assigned.

\item {} 
\code{coordinate}- (Optional; default=None) An integer in
\{0, ..., d-1\} indicating a convenient coordinate to base
the asymptotic calculations on.
If None is assigned, then choose \code{coordinate=d-1}.

\item {} 
\code{numerical} - (Optional; default=0) A natural number.
If numerical \textgreater{} 0, then return a numerical approximation of the
Maclaurin ray coefficients of \code{self} with \code{numerical} digits
of precision.
Otherwise return exact values.

\end{itemize}

NOTES:

The formulas used for computing the asymptotic expansion are
Theorem 3.4 and Theorem 3.7 of {\hyperref[amgf:rawi2012]{{[}RaWi2012{]}}}.

EXAMPLES:

\index{asymptotics\_smooth() (amgf.FFPD method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{amgf:amgf.FFPD.asymptotics_smooth}\pysiglinewithargsret{\bfcode{asymptotics\_smooth}}{\emph{p}, \emph{alpha}, \emph{N}, \emph{asy\_var}, \emph{coordinate=None}, \emph{numerical=0}}{}
Does what asymptotics() does but only in the case of a
convenient smooth point.

INPUT:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\code{p} - A dictionary with keys that can be coerced to equal
\code{self.ring().gens()}.

\item {} 
\code{alpha} - A tuple of length \code{d = self.dimension()} of
positive integers or, if \$p\$ is a smooth point,
possibly of symbolic variables.

\item {} 
\code{N} - A positive integer.

\item {} 
\code{asy\_var} - (Optional; default=None) A symbolic variable.
The variable of the asymptotic expansion.
If none is given, \code{var('r')} will be assigned.

\item {} 
\code{coordinate}- (Optional; default=None) An integer in
\{0, ..., d-1\} indicating a convenient coordinate to base
the asymptotic calculations on.
If None is assigned, then choose \code{coordinate=d-1}.

\item {} 
\code{numerical} - (Optional; default=0) A natural number.
If numerical \textgreater{} 0, then return a numerical approximation of the
Maclaurin ray coefficients of \code{self} with \code{numerical} digits
of precision.
Otherwise return exact values.

\end{itemize}

NOTES:

The formulas used for computing the asymptotic expansions are
Theorems 3.2 and 3.3 {\hyperref[amgf:rawi2008a]{{[}RaWi2008a{]}}} with the exponent of H equal to 1.
Theorem 3.2 is a specialization of Theorem 3.4 of {\hyperref[amgf:rawi2012]{{[}RaWi2012{]}}}
with $n=1$.

\index{coerce\_point() (amgf.FFPD static method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{amgf:amgf.FFPD.coerce_point}\pysiglinewithargsret{\strong{static }\bfcode{coerce\_point}}{\emph{R}, \emph{p}}{}
Coerce the keys of the dictionary \code{p} into the ring \code{R}.

Assume that it is possible.

EXAMPLES:

\index{cohomology\_decomposition() (amgf.FFPD method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{amgf:amgf.FFPD.cohomology_decomposition}\pysiglinewithargsret{\bfcode{cohomology\_decomposition}}{}{}
Let $p/(q_1^{e_1} \cdots q_n^{e_n})$ be the fraction represented
by \code{self} and let $K[x_1, \ldots, x_d]$ be the polynomial ring
in which the $q_i$ lie.
Assume that $n \le d$ and that the gradients of the $q_i$ are linearly
independent at all points in the intersection
$V_1 \cap \ldots \cap V_n$ of the algebraic varieties
$V_i = \{x \in L^d: q_i(x) = 0 \}$, where $L$ is the algebraic closure
of the field $K$.
Return a FFPDSum $f$ such that the differential form
$f dx_1 \wedge \cdots \wedge dx_d$ is de Rham cohomologous to the
differential form
$p/(q_1^{e_1} \cdots q_n^{e_n}) dx_1 \wedge \cdots \wedge dx_d$
and such that the denominator of each summand of $f$ contains
no repeated irreducible factors.

EXAMPLES:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{n}{R}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{o}{\textless{}}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{o}{\textgreater{}} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{PolynomialRing}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{QQ}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{n}{f} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{o}{\PYGZca{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n}{x} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{\PYGZca{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{3}
\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{n}{decomp} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{FFPD}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{quotient}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{f}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{cohomology\PYGZus{}decomposition}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{k}{print} \PYG{n}{decomp}

\index{crit\_cone\_combo() (amgf.FFPD method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{amgf:amgf.FFPD.crit_cone_combo}\pysiglinewithargsret{\bfcode{crit\_cone\_combo}}{\emph{p}, \emph{alpha}, \emph{coordinate=None}}{}
Return an auxiliary point associated to the multiple
point \code{p} of the factors \code{self}.
For internal use by asymptotics\_multiple().

INPUT:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\code{p} - A dictionary with keys that can be coerced to equal
\code{self.ring().gens()}.

\item {} 
\code{alpha} - A list of rationals.

\end{itemize}

OUTPUT:

A solution of the matrix equation $y \Gamma = \alpha'$ for $y$ ,
where $\Gamma$ is the matrix given by
\code{{[}FFPD.direction(v) for v in self.log\_grads(p){]}} and $\alpha'$
is \code{FFPD.direction(alpha)}

EXAMPLES:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{sage.combinat.asymptotics\PYGZus{}multivariate\PYGZus{}generating\PYGZus{}functions} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{o}{*}
\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{n}{R}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{o}{\textless{}}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{y}\PYG{o}{\textgreater{}}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{PolynomialRing}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{QQ}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{n}{p} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{exp}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{n}{df} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1} \PYG{o}{-} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{x} \PYG{o}{-} \PYG{n}{y}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1} \PYG{o}{-} \PYG{n}{x} \PYG{o}{-} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{y}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{]}
\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{n}{f} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{FFPD}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{p}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{df}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{n}{p} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{l+m+mi}{3}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{y}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{l+m+mi}{3}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{n}{alpha} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{var}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{'}\PYG{l+s}{a}\PYG{l+s}{'}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{var}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{'}\PYG{l+s}{b}\PYG{l+s}{'}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{k}{print} \PYG{n}{f}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{crit\PYGZus{}cone\PYGZus{}combo}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{p}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{alpha}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+go}{[1/3*(2*a - b)/b, -2/3*(a - 2*b)/b]}
\end{Verbatim}

NOTES:

Use this function only when $\Gamma$ is well-defined and
there is a unique solution to the matrix equation
$y \Gamma = \alpha'$.
Fails otherwise.

\index{critical\_cone() (amgf.FFPD method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{amgf:amgf.FFPD.critical_cone}\pysiglinewithargsret{\bfcode{critical\_cone}}{\emph{p}, \emph{coordinate=None}}{}
Return the critical cone of the convenient multiple point \code{p}.

INPUT:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\code{p} - A dictionary with keys that can be coerced to equal
\code{self.ring().gens()} and values in a field.

\item {} 
\code{coordinate} - (Optional; default=None) A natural number.

\end{itemize}

OUTPUT:

A list of vectors that generate the critical cone of \code{p} and
the cone itself, which is None if the values of \code{p} don't lie in QQ.
Divide logarithmic gradients by their component \code{coordinate} entries.
If \code{coordinate=None}, then search from d-1 down to 0 for the
first index j such that for all i \code{self.log\_grads(){[}i{]}{[}j{]} != 0}
and set \code{coordinate=j}.

\index{diff\_all() (amgf.FFPD static method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{amgf:amgf.FFPD.diff_all}\pysiglinewithargsret{\strong{static }\bfcode{diff\_all}}{\emph{f}, \emph{V}, \emph{n}, \emph{ending=}\optional{}, \emph{sub=None}, \emph{sub\_final=None}, \emph{zero\_order=0}, \emph{rekey=None}}{}
Return a dictionary of representative mixed partial
derivatives of $f$ from order 1 up to order $n$ with respect to the
variables in $V$.
The default is to key the dictionary by all nondecreasing sequences
in $V$ of length 1 up to length $n$.
For internal use.

INPUT:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\code{f} - An individual or list of $\mathcal{C}^{n+1}$ functions.

\item {} 
\code{V} - A list of variables occurring in $f$.

\item {} 
\code{n} - A natural number.

\item {} 
\code{ending} - A list of variables in $V$.

\item {} 
\code{sub} - An individual or list of dictionaries.

\item {} 
\code{sub\_final} - An individual or list of dictionaries.

\item {} 
\code{rekey} - A callable symbolic function in $V$ or list thereof.

\item {} 
\code{zero\_order} - A natural number.

\end{itemize}

OUTPUT:

The dictionary ${s_1:deriv_1,..., s_r:deriv_r}$.
Here $s_1,\ldots, s_r$ is a listing of
all nondecreasing sequences of length 1 up to length $n$ over the
alphabet $V$, where $w > v$ in $X$ iff $str(w) > str(v)$, and
$deriv_j$ is the derivative of $f$ with respect to the derivative
sequence $s_j$ and simplified with respect to the substitutions in
$sub$ and evaluated at $sub_final$.
Moreover, all derivatives with respect to sequences of length less than
$zero_order$ (derivatives of order less than $zero_order$ )
will be made zero.

If $rekey$ is nonempty, then $s_1,\ldots, s_r$ will be replaced by the
symbolic derivatives of the functions in $rekey$.

If $ending$ is nonempty, then every derivative sequence $s_j$ will be
suffixed by $ending$.

EXAMPLES:

I'd like to print the entire dictionaries, but that doesn't yield
consistent output order for doctesting.

\index{diff\_op() (amgf.FFPD static method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{amgf:amgf.FFPD.diff_op}\pysiglinewithargsret{\strong{static }\bfcode{diff\_op}}{\emph{A}, \emph{B}, \emph{AB\_derivs}, \emph{V}, \emph{M}, \emph{r}, \emph{N}}{}
Return the derivatives $DD^(l+k)(A[j] B^l)$ evaluated at a point
$p$ for various natural numbers $j, k, l$ which depend on $r$ and $N$.
Here $DD$ is a specific second-order linear differential operator
that depends on $M$ , $A$ is a list of symbolic functions,
$B$ is symbolic function, and $AB_derivs$ contains all the derivatives
of $A$ and $B$ evaluated at $p$ that are necessary for the computation.
For internal use by the functions asymptotics\_smooth() and
asymptotics\_multiple().

INPUT:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\code{A} - A single or length \code{r} list of symbolic functions in the
variables \code{V}.

\item {} 
\code{B} - A symbolic function in the variables \code{V}.

\item {} 
\code{AB\_derivs} - A dictionary whose keys are the (symbolic)
derivatives of \code{A{[}0{]}, ..., A{[}r-1{]}} up to order \code{2*N-2} and
the (symbolic) derivatives of \code{B} up to order \code{2*N}.
The values of the dictionary are complex numbers that are
the keys evaluated at a common point \$p\$.

\item {} 
\code{V} - The variables of the \code{A{[}j{]}} and \code{B}.

\item {} 
\code{M} - A symmetric $l \times l$ matrix, where $l$ is the
length of \code{V}.

\item {} 
\code{r, N} - Natural numbers.

\end{itemize}

OUTPUT:

A dictionary whose keys are natural number tuples of the form
$(j, k, l)$, where $l \le 2k$, $j \le r-1$, and $j+k \le N-1$,
and whose values are $DD^(l+k)(A[j] B^l)$ evaluated at a point
$p$, where $DD$ is the linear second-order differential operator
$-\sum_{i=0}^{l-1} \sum_{j=0}^{l-1} M[i][j]
\partial^2 /(\partial V[j] \partial V[i])$.

EXAMPLES:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{n}{T} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{var}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{'}\PYG{l+s}{x, y}\PYG{l+s}{'}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{n}{A} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{function}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{'}\PYG{l+s}{A}\PYG{l+s}{'}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n+nb}{tuple}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{T}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{n}{B} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{function}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{'}\PYG{l+s}{B}\PYG{l+s}{'}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n+nb}{tuple}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{T}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{n}{DD} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{FFPD}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{diff\PYGZus{}op}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{A}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{B}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{AB\PYGZus{}derivs}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{T}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{M}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{n}{DD}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{keys}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+go}{[(0, 1, 2), (0, 1, 1), (0, 1, 0), (0, 0, 0)]}
\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{n+nb}{len}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{DD}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+go}{246}
\end{Verbatim}

AUTHORS:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Alexander Raichev (2008-10-01, 2010-01-12)

\index{diff\_op\_simple() (amgf.FFPD static method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{amgf:amgf.FFPD.diff_op_simple}\pysiglinewithargsret{\strong{static }\bfcode{diff\_op\_simple}}{\emph{A}, \emph{B}, \emph{AB\_derivs}, \emph{x}, \emph{v}, \emph{a}, \emph{N}}{}
Return $DD^(e k + v l)(A B^l)$ evaluated at a point $p$ for
various natural numbers $e, k, l$ that depend on $v$ and $N$.
Here $DD$ is a specific linear differential operator that depends
on $a$ and $v$ , $A$ and $B$ are symbolic functions, and $AB_derivs$
contains all the derivatives of $A$ and $B$ evaluated at $p$ that are
necessary for the computation.
For internal use by the function asymptotics\_smooth().

INPUT:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\code{A, B} - Symbolic functions in the variable \code{x}.

\item {} 
\code{AB\_derivs} - A dictionary whose keys are the (symbolic)
derivatives of \code{A} up to order \code{2*N} if \code{v} is even or
\code{N} if \code{v} is odd and the (symbolic) derivatives of \code{B}
up to order \code{2*N + v} if \code{v} is even or \code{N + v}
if \code{v} is odd.
The values of the dictionary are complex numbers that are
the keys evaluated at a common point \$p\$.

\item {} 
\code{x} - Symbolic variable.

\item {} 
\code{a} - A complex number.

\item {} 
\code{v, N} - Natural numbers.

\end{itemize}

OUTPUT:

A dictionary whose keys are natural number pairs of the form $(k, l)$,
where $k < N$ and $l \le 2k$ and whose values are
$DD^(e k + v l)(A B^l)$ evaluated at a point $p$.
Here $e=2$ if $v$ is even, $e=1$ if $v$ is odd, and $DD$ is the
linear differential operator
$(a^{-1/v} d/dt)$ if $v$ is even and
$(|a|^{-1/v} i \text{sgn}(a) d/dt)$ if $v$ is odd.

EXAMPLES:

\index{diff\_prod() (amgf.FFPD static method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{amgf:amgf.FFPD.diff_prod}\pysiglinewithargsret{\strong{static }\bfcode{diff\_prod}}{\emph{f\_derivs}, \emph{u}, \emph{g}, \emph{X}, \emph{interval}, \emph{end}, \emph{uderivs}, \emph{atc}}{}
Take various derivatives of the equation $f = ug$,
evaluate them at a point $c$, and solve for the derivatives of $u$.
For internal use by the function asymptotics\_multiple().

INPUT:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\code{f\_derivs} - A dictionary whose keys are all tuples of the form
\code{s + end}, where \code{s} is a sequence of variables from \code{X} whose
length lies in \code{interval}, and whose values are the derivatives
of a function \$f\$ evaluated at \$c\$.

\item {} 
\code{u} - A callable symbolic function.

\item {} 
\code{g} - An expression or callable symbolic function.

\item {} 
\code{X} - A list of symbolic variables.

\item {} 
\code{interval} - A list of positive integers.
Call the first and last values \$n\$ and \$nn\$, respectively.

\item {} 
\code{end} - A possibly empty list of repetitions of the
variable \code{z}, where \code{z} is the last element of \code{X}.

\item {} 
\code{uderivs} - A dictionary whose keys are the symbolic
derivatives of order 0 to order \$n-1\$ of \code{u} evaluated at \$c\$
and whose values are the corresponding derivatives evaluated
at \$c\$.

\item {} 
\code{atc} - A dictionary whose keys are the keys of $c$ and all
the symbolic derivatives of order 0 to order \$nn\$ of \code{g}
evaluated \$c\$ and whose values are the corresponding
derivatives evaluated at \$c\$.

\end{itemize}

OUTPUT:

A dictionary whose keys are the derivatives of \code{u} up to order
$nn$ and whose values are those derivatives evaluated at $c$.

EXAMPLES:

I'd like to print out the entire dictionary, but that does not give
consistent output for doctesting.
Order of keys changes

\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{n}{atc} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{g}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{3}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{diff}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{g}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{5}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{n}{atc}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{diff}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{g}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{7}
\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{n}{dd} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{FFPD}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{diff\PYGZus{}prod}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{fd}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{u}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{g}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{ud}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{atc}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{n}{dd}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{diff}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{u}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{]}
\PYG{g+go}{22/9}
\end{Verbatim}

NOTES:

This function works by differentiating the equation $f = ug$
with respect to the variable sequence \code{s + end},
for all tuples \code{s} of \code{X} of lengths in \code{interval},
evaluating at the point $c$ ,
and solving for the remaining derivatives of \code{u}.
This function assumes that \code{u} never appears in the
differentiations of $f = ug$ after evaluating at $c$.

AUTHORS:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Alexander Raichev (2009-05-14, 2010-01-21)

\end{itemize}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{diff\_seq() (amgf.FFPD static method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{amgf:amgf.FFPD.diff_seq}\pysiglinewithargsret{\strong{static }\bfcode{diff\_seq}}{\emph{V}, \emph{s}}{}
Given a list \code{s} of tuples of natural numbers, return the
list of elements of \code{V} with indices the elements of the elements
of \code{s}.
This function is for internal use by the function diff\_op().

INPUT:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\code{V} - A list.

\item {} 
\code{s} - A list of tuples of natural numbers in the interval
\code{range(len(V))}.

\end{itemize}

OUTPUT:

The tuple \code{tuple({[}V{[}tt{]} for tt in sorted(t){]})}, where \code{t} is the
list of elements of the elements of \code{s}.

\index{is\_convenient\_multiple\_point() (amgf.FFPD method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{amgf:amgf.FFPD.is_convenient_multiple_point}\pysiglinewithargsret{\bfcode{is\_convenient\_multiple\_point}}{\emph{p}}{}
Return True if \code{p} is a convenient multiple point of \code{self} and
False otherwise.
Also return a short comment.

INPUT:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\code{p} - A dictionary with keys that can be coerced to equal
\code{self.ring().gens()}.

\end{itemize}

OUTPUT:

A pair (verdict, comment).
In case \code{p} is a convenient multiple point, verdict=True and
comment ='No problem'.
In case \code{p} is not, verdict=False and comment is string explaining
why \code{p} fails to be a convenient multiple point.

EXAMPLES:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{n}{R}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{o}{\textless{}}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{y}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{z}\PYG{o}{\textgreater{}}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{PolynomialRing}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{GF}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s}{'}\PYG{l+s}{a}\PYG{l+s}{'}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{n}{f} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{y} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{z} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{y} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n}{z}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{n}{decomp} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{FFPD}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{quotient}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{f}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{leinartas\PYGZus{}decomposition}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{k}{print} \PYG{n}{decomp}
\PYG{g+go}{[(0, []), (1, [(z, 2), (x*y + z, 1)]),}
\PYG{g+go}{(1, [(z, 2), (y, 1), (x, 1)])]}
\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{k}{print} \PYG{n}{decomp}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{sum}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{quotient}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{n}{f}
\PYG{g+go}{True}
\end{Verbatim}

NOTE:

Let $f = p/q$ where $q$ lies in a $d$ -variate polynomial ring $K[X]$
for some field $K$.
Let $q_1^{e_1} \cdots q_n^{e_n}$ be the
unique factorization of $q$ in $K[X]$ into irreducible factors and
let $V_i$ be the algebraic variety
$\{x\in L^d: q_i(x) = 0\}$ of $q_i$ over the algebraic closure
$L$ of $K$.
By {\hyperref[amgf:raic2012]{{[}Raic2012{]}}}, $f$ can be written as

(*)   $\sum p_A/\prod_{i \in A} q_i^{b_i}$,

where the $b_i$ are positive integers, each $p_A$ is a product of $p$ and an element of $K[X]$, 
and the sum is taken over all subsets $A \subseteq \{1, \ldots, m\}$ such that 
(1) $|A| \le d$,
(2) $\cap_{i\in A} T_i \neq \emptyset$, and
(3) $\{q_i : i\in A\}$ is algebraically independent.

In particular, any rational expression in $d$ variables
can be represented as a sum of rational expressions
whose denominators each contain at most $d$ distinct irreducible
factors.

I call (*) a \emph{Leinartas decomposition} of $f$.
Leinartas decompositions are not unique.

The algorithm used comes from {\hyperref[amgf:raic2012]{{[}Raic2012{]}}}.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{log\_grads() (amgf.FFPD method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{amgf:amgf.FFPD.log_grads}\pysiglinewithargsret{\bfcode{log\_grads}}{\emph{p}}{}
Return a list of the logarithmic gradients of the polynomials
\code{{[}q for (q, e) in self.denominator\_factored(){]}} evalutated at \code{p}.

INPUT:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\code{p} - (Optional: default=None) A dictionary whose keys are the
generators of \code{self.ring()}.

\end{itemize}

NOTE:

The logarithmic gradient of a function $f$ at point $p$ is the vector
$(x_1 \partial_1 f(x), \ldots, x_d \partial_d f(x) )$ evaluated at
$p$.

\index{maclaurin\_coefficients() (amgf.FFPD method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{amgf:amgf.FFPD.maclaurin_coefficients}\pysiglinewithargsret{\bfcode{maclaurin\_coefficients}}{\emph{multi\_indices}, \emph{numerical=0}}{}
Returns the Maclaurin coefficients of self that have multi-indices
in \code{multi\_indices}.

INPUT:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\code{multi\_indices} - A list of tuples of positive integers, where
each tuple has length \code{self.dimension()}.

\item {} 
\code{numerical} - (Optional; default=0) A natural number.
If positive, return numerical
approximations of coefficients with \code{numerical} digits of
accuracy.

\end{itemize}

OUTPUT:

(nu, Maclaurin coefficient of index nu of self).

\index{nullstellensatz\_certificate() (amgf.FFPD method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{amgf:amgf.FFPD.nullstellensatz_certificate}\pysiglinewithargsret{\bfcode{nullstellensatz\_certificate}}{}{}
Let $[(q_1, e_1), \ldots, (q_n, e_n)]$ be the denominator factorization
of \code{self}.
Return a list of polynomials $h_1, \ldots, h_m$ in \code{self.ring()}
that satisfies $h_1 q_1 + \cdots + h_m q_n = 1$ if it exists.
Otherwise return None.
Only works for multivariate \code{self}.

EXAMPLES:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{n}{R}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{o}{\textless{}}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{y}\PYG{o}{\textgreater{}} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{PolynomialRing}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{QQ}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{n}{L} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{f}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{nullstellensatz\PYGZus{}certificate}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{g+go}{[(0, []), (1, [(x, 1)]), (-y, [(x*y + 1, 1)])]}
\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{n}{decomp}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{sum}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{quotient}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{n}{f}
\PYG{g+go}{True}

\PYG{g+gp}{... }      \PYG{n}{L} \PYG{o+ow}{is} \PYG{n+nb+bp}{None}
\PYG{g+gp}{...}
\PYG{g+go}{True}
\PYG{g+go}{True}

\end{Verbatim}

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{n}{R}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{o}{\textless{}}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{y}\PYG{o}{\textgreater{}} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{PolynomialRing}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{QQ}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{n}{G} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{sin}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{y}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{n}{H} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{x}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{y} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{n}{f} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{FFPD}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{G}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{H}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{factor}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{n}{decomp} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{f}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{nullstellensatz\PYGZus{}decomposition}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{k}{print} \PYG{n}{decomp}
\PYG{g+go}{[(0, []), (sin(y), [(x, 1)]), (-y*sin(y), [(x*y + 1, 1)])]}
\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{n+nb}{bool}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{decomp}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{sum}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{quotient}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{n}{G}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{H}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+go}{True}
\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{k}{for} \PYG{n}{r} \PYG{o+ow}{in} \PYG{n}{decomp}\PYG{p}{:}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }      \PYG{n}{L} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{r}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{nullstellensatz\PYGZus{}certificate}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{... }      \PYG{n}{L} \PYG{o+ow}{is} \PYG{n+nb+bp}{None}
\PYG{g+gp}{...}
\PYG{g+go}{True}
\PYG{g+go}{True}
\PYG{g+go}{True}
\end{Verbatim}

NOTE:

Let $f = p/q$ where $q$ lies in a $d$ -variate polynomial ring $K[X]$ for some field $K$ and $d \ge 1$.
Let $q_1^{e_1} \cdots q_n^{e_n}$ be the
unique factorization of $q$ in $K[X]$ into irreducible factors and
let $V_i$ be the algebraic variety $\{x \in L^d: q_i(x) = 0\}$ of
$q_i$ over the algebraic closure $L$ of $K$.
By {\hyperref[amgf:raic2012]{{[}Raic2012{]}}}, $f$ can be written as

(*)   $\sum p_A/\prod_{i \in A} q_i^{e_i}$,

where the $p_A$ are products of $p$ and elements in $K[X]$ and
the sum is taken over all subsets
$A \subseteq \{1, \ldots, m\}$ such that
$\cap_{i\in A} T_i \neq \emptyset$.

I call (*) a \emph{Nullstellensatz decomposition} of $f$.
Nullstellensatz decompositions are not unique.

The algorithm used comes from {\hyperref[amgf:raic2012]{{[}Raic2012{]}}}.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{permutation\_sign() (amgf.FFPD static method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{amgf:amgf.FFPD.permutation_sign}\pysiglinewithargsret{\strong{static }\bfcode{permutation\_sign}}{\emph{s}, \emph{u}}{}
This function returns the sign of the permutation on
\code{1, ..., len(u)} that is induced by the sublist
\code{s} of \code{u}.
For internal use by cohomology\_decomposition().

INPUT:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\code{s} - A sublist of \code{u}.

\item {} 
\code{u} - A list.

\end{itemize}

OUTPUT:

The sign of the permutation obtained by taking indices
within \code{u} of the list \code{s + sc}, where \code{sc} is \code{u}
with the elements of \code{s} removed.

\index{relative\_error() (amgf.FFPD method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{amgf:amgf.FFPD.relative_error}\pysiglinewithargsret{\bfcode{relative\_error}}{\emph{approx}, \emph{alpha}, \emph{interval}, \emph{exp\_scale=1}, \emph{digits=10}}{}
Returns the relative error between the values of the Maclaurin
coefficients of \code{self} with multi-indices \code{r alpha} for \code{r} in
\code{interval} and the values of the functions (of the variable \code{r})
in \code{approx}.

INPUT:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\code{approx} - An individual or list of symbolic expressions in
one variable.

\item {} 
\code{alpha} - A list of positive integers of length
\code{self.ring().ngens()}

\item {} 
\code{interval} - A list of positive integers.

\item {} 
\code{exp\_scale} - (Optional; default=1) A number.

\end{itemize}

OUTPUT:

A list whose entries are of the form
\code{{[}r*alpha, a\_r, b\_r, err\_r{]}} for \code{r} in \code{interval}.
Here \code{r*alpha} is a tuple; \code{a\_r} is the \code{r*alpha} (multi-index)
coefficient of the Maclaurin series for \code{self} divided by
\code{exp\_scale**r};
\code{b\_r} is a list of the values of the functions in \code{approx}
evaluated at \code{r} and divided by \code{exp\_scale**m};
\code{err\_r} is the list of relative errors
\code{(a\_r - f)/a\_r} for \code{f} in \code{b\_r}.
All outputs are decimal approximations.

EXAMPLES:

\index{singular\_ideal() (amgf.FFPD method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{amgf:amgf.FFPD.singular_ideal}\pysiglinewithargsret{\bfcode{singular\_ideal}}{}{}
Let $R$ be the ring of \code{self} and $H$ its denominator.
Let $Hred$ be the reduction (square-free part) of $H$.
Return the ideal in $R$ generated by $Hred$ and
its partial derivatives.
If the coefficient field of $R$ is algebraically closed,
then the output is the ideal of the singular locus (which is a variety)
of the variety of $H$.

EXAMPLES:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{sage.combinat.asymptotics\PYGZus{}multivariate\PYGZus{}generating\PYGZus{}functions} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{o}{*}
\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{n}{R}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{o}{\textless{}}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{y}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{z}\PYG{o}{\textgreater{}}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{PolynomialRing}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{QQ}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{n}{H} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1} \PYG{o}{-} \PYG{n}{x}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n}{y}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{l+m+mi}{3}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1} \PYG{o}{-} \PYG{n}{z}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{y}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{n}{df} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{H}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{factor}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{n}{G} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{df}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{unit}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{n}{F} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{FFPD}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{G}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{df}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{g+go}{of Multivariate Polynomial Ring in x, y, z over Rational Field}
\end{Verbatim}

\index{smooth\_critical\_ideal() (amgf.FFPD method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{amgf:amgf.FFPD.smooth_critical_ideal}\pysiglinewithargsret{\bfcode{smooth\_critical\_ideal}}{\emph{alpha}}{}
Let $R$ be the ring of \code{self} and $H$ its denominator.
Return the ideal in $R$ of smooth critical points of the variety
of $H$ for the direction \code{alpha}.
If the variety $V$ of $H$ has no smooth points, then return the ideal
in $R$ of $V$.

INPUT:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\code{alpha} - A d-tuple of positive integers and/or symbolic entries,
where d = \code{self.ring().ngens()}.

\end{itemize}

EXAMPLES:

\index{subs\_all() (amgf.FFPD static method)}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{amgf:amgf.FFPD.subs_all}\pysiglinewithargsret{\strong{static }\bfcode{subs\_all}}{\emph{f}, \emph{sub}, \emph{simplify=False}}{}
Return the items of $f$ substituted by the dictionaries
of $sub$ in order of their appearance in $sub$.

INPUT:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\code{f} - An individual or list of symbolic expressions or dictionaries

\item {} 
\code{sub} - An individual or list of dictionaries.

\item {} 
\code{simplify} - Boolean (default: False).

\end{itemize}

OUTPUT:

The items of $f$ substituted by the dictionaries of $sub$ in order of
their appearance in $sub$.
The subs() command is used.
If simplify is True, then simplify() is used after substitution.

EXAMPLES:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

\index{univariate\_decomposition() (amgf.FFPD method)}

of \code{self} as a FFPDSum instance.

of a univariate factorial polynomial ring.

\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{n}{f} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{5}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{o}{\PYGZca{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{3} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{x} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{3}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{o}{\PYGZca{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{g+go}{(15.0000000000000*x\PYGZca{}7 - 15.0000000000000*x\PYGZca{}6 + 5.00000000000000*x\PYGZca{}5}
\PYG{g+go}{- 5.00000000000000*x\PYGZca{}4 + 6.00000000000000*x\PYGZca{}3 -}

\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{n}{decomp} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{FFPD}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{quotient}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{f}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{univariate\PYGZus{}decomposition}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{k}{print} \PYG{n}{decomp}
\PYG{g+go}{[(5.00000000000000*x\PYGZca{}3, []), (1.00000000000000,}
\PYG{g+go}{[(x - 1.00000000000000, 1)]), (-0.288675134594813*I,}
\PYG{g+go}{[(x - 0.577350269189626*I, 1)]), (1.00000000000000, [(x, 1)]),}
\PYG{g+go}{(0.288675134594813*I, [(x + 0.577350269189626*I, 1)])]}
\PYG{g+gp}{sage: }\PYG{k}{print} \PYG{n}{decomp}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{sum}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{quotient}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{n}{f} \PYG{c}{\# Rounding error coming}
\PYG{g+go}{False}
\end{Verbatim}

NOTE:

Let $f = p/q$ be a rational expression where $p$ and $q$ lie in a
univariate factorial polynomial ring $R$.
Let $q_1^{e_1} \cdots q_n^{e_n}$ be the
unique factorization of $q$ in $R$ into irreducible factors.
Then $f$ can be written uniquely as

(*)   $p_0 + \sum_{i=1}^{m} p_i/ q_i^{e_i}$,

for some $p_j \in R$.
I call (*) the \emph{usual partial fraction decomposition} of f.

AUTHORS:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Robert Bradshaw (2007-05-31)

\item {} 
Alexander Raichev (2012-06-25)

\end{itemize}

\end{fulllineitems}


\end{fulllineitems}
